column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-shooting-guns-idUSKCN0ZA395	Bipartisan U.S. House members vow to keep gun control fight alive	"
By Richard Cowan
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON A bipartisan group of lawmakers on Friday pledged to build support in the U.S. House of Representatives for legislation keeping firearms from people on terrorism watch lists
column2: despite repeated gun control failures this week in Congress.The ""Terrorist Firearms Prevention Act"" was introduced by nine House members representing diverse states stretching from Hawaii to Delaware
column3: including some who have led the gun control fight for years.""If you can't get on a plane because of the danger that may pose
column4: there is no reason you should be able to purchase a dangerous weapon
column5: said Republican Representative Carlos Curbelo of Florida
column6: in a refrain that has ricocheted through the U.S. Capitol since the June 12 mass shooting in Orlando.The legislation
column7: identical to a bill by Senator Susan Collins of Maine that was debated on the Senate floor on Thursday
column8: would halt sales of weapons to people on a ""no-fly"" list barring them from boarding airplanes
column9: or a ""Selectee"" list in which they are subjected to special airport screenings.

column1: Over the past two weeks
column2: the Senate failed to advance this or several other proposals placing new constraints on gun sales
column3: as the U.S. mourned the deaths of 49 people killed at an Orlando nightclub with 53 others injured.Curbelo said he met with House Speaker Paul Ryan's top aide to inform him of the bill. The lawmaker left that meeting with no assurances it would advance
column4: but simply ""no objection from the speaker's office"" to the legislation being introduced
column5: Curbelo said.

column1: He added that the bill's sponsors now must build support ""amongst our colleagues"" in a House that has a concentration of conservative Republicans opposed to most gun control ideas.Many Republicans have argued that travelers can mistakenly be placed on terrorism watch lists and denying them the ability to buy weapons would stomp on their constitutional rights.
We cannot let that argument stop
column2: into perpetuity
column3: our ability to advance wise legislation in this matter
column4: countered    Republican Representative Scott Rigell of Virginia.Rigell
column5: a co-sponsor of the bill
column6: introduced himself to reporters at a press conference as a lifetime member of the National Rifle Association
column9: including an AR-15 semi-automatic rifle that is similar to the weapon used by Omar Mateen
column10: the Orlando shooter. (Reporting By Richard Cowan; Editing by David Gregorio)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-cash-idUSKCN0Z91CL	"Trump's ""unlimited"" wealth may not be enough to fund his campaign"	"
By Tom Bergin
| LONDON
LONDON New York real estate developer Donald Trump says he has ""unlimited"" personal wealth to fund his White House run
column2: but a Reuters review of his financial disclosures suggests he does not have enough cash to see his campaign through to Election Day.Trump this week dismissed concerns about his campaign finances after electoral filings showed he raised just $3 million in individual contributions in May and had a war chest of only $1 million at the end of the month. His Democratic rival
column3: Hillary Clinton
column4: raised $26 million and ended May with a war chest of $42 million. Trump
column5: the presumptive Republican nominee who says he is worth about $10 billion
column6: said in a statement on Tuesday that ""if need be
column7: there could be unlimited 'cash on hand' as I would put up my own money."" Trump had cash and other liquid investments - money in funds
column8: equities and cash - worth $60 million to $180 million in May
column9: according to his filings with the Office of Government Ethics. The form does not require candidates to give precise values for their assets
column10: only ranges.If President Barack Obama's spending in his successful re-election bid in 2012 election is any guide
column11: then Trump is a few hundred million dollars short. Obama spent almost $600 million between June and November 2012
column12: according to Federal Election Commission filings.Trump's campaign declined to comment for this story but referred to his earlier statement
column13: in which he said his White House bid costs less than a traditional one because it is ""leaner and more efficient."" If Trump did decide to self-finance his campaign

column17: much of an entrepreneur's corporate earnings are often used to invest in building their businesses and maintaining their property assets. Trump's liquid assets stood at $80 million to $230 million in July last year
column18: according to an earlier electoral filing. Using the midpoint of the ranges

column25: which do not give a precise picture of Trump's wealth.""It's quite possible that he doesn't have anywhere near what he suggests he has and what he does have is tied up in real estate
column26: and selling that is no easy task

column9: or primaries.If Trump does not use his own money

column1: THE GROUND GAME
Trump has spent around $63 million so far in his presidential bid
column2: including $46 million in loans he made to his campaign
column3: FERC data shows. Typically
column4: television advertising and creating infrastructure at a state and local level to mobilize voters are the most expensive aspects of a U.S. presidential campaign. TV networks charge high fees for prime time slots and many ground troops needed to bring out the voters must be paid. So far Trump has not needed to spend much on television advertising - his fiery rhetoric on illegal immigrants and what he says are the security risks posed by refugees from the Middle East have guaranteed him blanket media coverage. Daniel Weiner
column5: a campaign finance expert at New York University's Brennan Center for Justice said you can get only so far with free media in an election.

column1: TV advertising has been decreasing in importance for a long time
column2: but the get-out-the vote stuff is crucial
column3: particularly in an election that people perceive as being more about motivating their core voters
column4: as opposed to winning over swing voters. And what we call 'the ground game' is quite expensive
column5: he said.Trump has said he plans to outsource some of that ground game to the RNC
column6: for example relying on their field staff in battleground states to help get out the vote.BANKING ON BUILDINGS

column1: Trump has significant real estate holdings

column3: some real estate experts say selling them to generate cash would be a challenge.But several bankers say Trump could conceivably borrow hundreds of millions against them
column4: despite his history of business bankruptcies and litigation with lenders.Exactly how much he could borrow
column5: how easily and at what interest rates depends on how much Trump owns of the buildings that he cites as his own and how much debt he has.""You have years of prosperity and you have all of these alternative lenders and you have banks that are hungry for loans

column2: ACLU agree on protest limits at Republican convention	"

column1: By Kim Palmer
| CLEVELAND
CLEVELAND The city of Cleveland and the American Civil Liberties Union on Friday settled a federal lawsuit over free speech limits outside the Republican National Convention next month
column2: setting the stage for lively demonstrations during Donald Trump's big moment.The city had been seeking a restricted zone of 3.3 square miles (8.5 square km) around the Quicken Loans Arena
column3: site of the convention
column4: where free speech and mobility would be limited. That prompted an ACLU lawsuit on behalf of three protest groups that argued the so-called event zone was too large and the security regulations too strict.Details of the new event zone and protest rules were not immediately available.""Today
column5: counsel advised me that the case is settled and that they will execute a settlement agreement expeditiously
column6: U.S. District Judge Dan Aaron Polster said in a statement.

column1: Another judge on Thursday had struck down Cleveland's plan for placing limits on protests
column2: issuing a preliminary injunction in favor of the ACLU and referring the case to Polster for mediation.Trump is expected to become the Republican Party's official nominee for president at the July 18-21 convention
column3: which will attract protesters for various causes who plan to demonstrate outside.

column1: Trump campaign events have drawn large and raucous demonstrations with some resulting in clashes between the candidate's supporters and opponents.The plaintiffs in the Cleveland lawsuit are Citizens for Trump

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-taxes-idUSKCN0ZA0E8	Ryan
column2: House Republicans offer plan to slice U.S. tax rates	"

column1: By Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Republicans in the U.S. House of Representatives said on Friday  they would advance legislation next year to chop individual and corporate U.S. tax rates.The tax plan
column2: unveiled by House Speaker Paul Ryan and other Republican lawmakers at the U.S. Capitol
column3: is the sixth and final plank of a conservative policy agenda being rolled out in an effort to unify Republicans after a divisive primary campaign for the party's presidential nominee.Ryan
column4: the highest-ranking elected Republican
column5: said the proposal would provide a clear direction for U.S. economic leadership and was needed amid global uncertainty that was exemplified by the British vote to leave the European Union.""For all of these moments of possible uncertainty that are happening around the globe
column9: American economic leadership is in need
column11: he said.Washington has been unable to summon the political will to reform the loophole-riddled tax code for nearly three decades. Overhauling the code has long been a goal of Ryan
column12: a self-described policy wonk. He was considered the Republican Party's leading voice on taxes and budgets before he ascended to the job of speaker last year.

column1: But the labor powerhouse AFL-CIO scorned the Republican blueprint as similar to a tax-cutting proposal made last year by presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump
column2: who Ryan recently endorsed.Ryan and Trump ""have striking resemblance - both tax plans benefit the wealthy & corps a lot
column3: the AFL-CIO said on Twitter. Trump's ideas about taxes have appeared contradictory at times. He said in May he is open to raising taxes on the rich
column4: backing off prior proposals to reduce taxes on all Americans and corporations by slashing rates even more deeply than Ryan and House Republicans would.

column1: Democrats
column2: including presidential front-runner Hillary Clinton
column3: have pressed for increased taxes on the wealthiest Americans for years.House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi criticized the Republican plan as ""massive tax giveaways to millionaires and billionaires on the backs of hard-working American families.""The plan would consolidate the current seven tax brackets for individuals to three
column4: and lower the top individual income tax rate from 39.6 percent to 33 percent
column5: higher than the 25 percent that Ryan proposed when he chaired the House Budget Committee.

column1: Ryan said the goal was to make things so simple the average American could do their taxes on a postcard.The plan would lead to a maximum tax rate of 25 percent on small business income. It would also lower the top U.S. corporate tax rate from 35 percent
column2: the highest in the industrialized world
column3: to 20 percent
column4: as well as shift to a ""territorial"" style tax system aimed at exempting the earnings of American companies abroad from U.S. taxation.The blueprint also calls for overhauling the tax-collecting Internal Revenue Service
column5: an idea that animates many conservatives who have called for its abolition. (Reporting by Susan Cornwell; Editing by Susan Heavey and Jeffrey Benkoe)"

By Ayesha Rascoe and Julia Harte
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The Obama administration on Friday rolled out a series of education and work training initiatives focused on helping convicted criminals avoid returning to prison
column2: part of President Barack Obama's legacy-shaping effort to overhaul the U.S. criminal justice system as he prepares to leave office.The measures include a program that will link 67 colleges and universities with 141 correctional facilities to provide education and training to about 12
column3: 000 inmates. The program will offer federal Pell grants to prisoners

column6: they too often end up back behind bars
column7: she said.Other programs unveiled on Friday will offer $31 million in grants for organizations to offer occupational training and apprenticeship opportunities for young adults and more than $5 million to organizations that help inmates prepare for employment.

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-idUSKCN0ZA0LT	Donald Trump heads for Scotland to reopen a golf resort	"
By Steve Holland
| GLASGOW
column2: Scotland

column1: GLASGOW
column2: Scotland Most U.S. presidential candidates go abroad to sharpen their foreign policy credentials. Donald Trump arrives in Scotland on Friday to reopen a golf resort.The presumptive Republican nominee
column4: visits his family's ancestral homeland to showcase his far-flung business empire. His mother was born on Scotland's Isle of Lewis.With a throng of reporters watching

column6: to be followed by a stop at his resort in Aberdeen on Saturday
column7: will allow him to comment on the outcome of Britain's vote on Thursday on whether to remain in the European Union.""I don't think opening a golf resort gets you many foreign policy chops

column11: who has yet to hold public office and rates unfavorably with 70 percent of Americans in an opinion poll
column12: will make a foreign policy misstep at a time when Republican leaders are urging a more serious demeanor.

column1: Trump has said he would be inclined to leave the EU. He has exchanged insults with British Prime Minister David Cameron

column5: director of the Paul Simon Public Policy Institute at Southern Illinois University. Turnberry is a storied course where the Open Championship has been staged four times. Trump invested $290 million in renovating the resort and golf course on Scotland's West Coast 85 km (53 miles) southwest of Glasgow.

column1: He has portrayed his determination to build up courses in Turnberry and Aberdeen and overcome local opposition as an example of the type of leadership skills that Americans would get if he wins the White House on Nov. 8.""Well

column3: Trump wrote in a column for The Press and Journal newspaper in Aberdeen.An Aberdeen family opposed to his development there has threatened to raise a Mexican flag as a reminder of his proposal to build a wall along the U.S. southern border to keep out immigrants who enter illegally.The last Republican presidential nominee
